awd_titl_txt: IDBR: The LuxArray Scanner: Surveying the Environment with Biomicroelectronic Cellular Reporter Arrays
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacterial bioreporters are designed to produce a measurable signal in response to a specific chemical or physical agent in their environment.  Since they are living sensors, they respond as a biological unit both continuously and in real-time to environmental changes. Moreover, they report on contaminant bioavailability (i.e., the effect the contaminant has on a living system) rather than merely on contaminant concentration, as most analytical methods do.  A suite of 689 E. coli bioreporters containing unique genetic promoters linked to the bioluminescent lux operon was designed by DuPont.  This "LuxArray" serves as a powerful tool to profile on a massive scale an organism's transcriptional response to its environment.  By monitoring those bacterial bioreporters that generate visible light, one can identify genes activated under known specific environmental conditions, such as the input of a chemical contaminant.  
The goal of this research effort is to establish the utility of the LuxArray as an environmental monitoring system using artificially spiked water samples and samples obtained from Chattanooga Creek, a coal tar contaminated field site located in Chattanooga, Tennessee.  LuxArray bioreporters will be tested both as free cells and as cells immobilized in a latex matrix.  The expected long-term outcome is a field deployable LuxArray instrument capable of continuously monitoring an environmental ecosystem and reporting in real-time chemical insults that may occur within that ecosystem with concurrent bioluminescent "fingerprint" identification of what those chemicals are.  Resulting data can then be used to forecast environmental health and contribute to models of predictive risk assessment.  Project activity and outcomes will be available at http://www.ceb.utk.edu.

por.por_cntn:
Bacteria and other microorganisms are ubiquitous within our environment and they have long been used for sensing, monitoring, and pre-warning of chemical impacts to our ecosystems that would translate into harmful consequences toward human and animal health. These microorganisms, referred to as bioreporters, are genetically designed to emit easy-to-measure signals like bioluminescent or fluorescent light when they contact targeted chemical contaminants. Interfacing bioreporters with miniaturized light detectors forms all-in-one environmental monitoring systems that are remote, deployable, and ideally capable of continuously monitoring and reporting on environmental conditions. This research effort more closely examined the sensitivity and specificity of bioreporter systems for continuous environmental surveillance and developed miniaturized sensors capable of performing remote and deployable sensing. The results of this research will assist in the evolution of autonomous sensing platforms that will survey water, soils, and air for chemical contaminants and pre-warn of conditions that may be harmful to human, animal, and wildlife health. The research involved eight undergraduate students and four high school students (42% female and 25% from under-represented groups) who performed challenging hands-on investigational activities.  These students additionally disseminated their research experiences to local grade schools and high schools in the community through participation in science fairs, the SHADES program (SHaring ADventures in Engineering & Science), a day-long series of science lab classes for girls in grades 5-8, and the Pre-Collegiate Research Scholars Program, which allows high school students to perform year-long research projects on the University campus. A publication in the Journal of Microbiology and Biology Education also resulted that described the use of jewelry as a practical and resourceful platform for teaching molecular biology to K-12 student populations. These outreach activities were leveraged to obtain University support for a designated laboratory workstation to facilitate an expanded undergraduate/high school student research workforce and a summer high school research experience examining the interaction of microbial communities in soil ecosystems. Ultimately, the molecular biology and bioreporter sensing experiments performed by our student scholars will translate into a research program that is expected to challenge nearly 100 undergraduate/high school student teams each year.
